ticket.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection
ticket.original-body: I'm sick of writing @@@ lang=ruby <% if search_results.empty? %> Nothing found <% else %> <%= render :partial => 'search_result', :collection => search_results %> <% end %> @@@ As far as I'm concerned the less actual code and branching in views, the better. Instead I propose @@@ <%= render :partial => 'search_result', :collection => search_results, :empty_template => 'nothing_found' %> @@@ With the nothing_found partial containing the obvious. (I'd rather have a better option name than empty_template but I haven't thought of one so far)
ticket.latest-body: I'm sick of writing @@@ lang=ruby <% if search_results.empty? %> Nothing found <% else %> <%= render :partial => 'search_result', :collection => search_results %> <% end %> @@@ As far as I'm concerned the less actual code and branching in views, the better. Instead I propose @@@ <%= render :partial => 'search_result', :collection => search_results, :empty_template => 'nothing_found' %> @@@ With the nothing_found partial containing the obvious. (I'd rather have a better option name than empty_template but I haven't thought of one so far)
ticket.original-body-html:
I'm sick of writing

@@@ lang=ruby <% if search_results.empty? %> Nothing found <% else %> <%= render :partial => 'search_result', :collection => search_results %> <% end %>



As far as I'm concerned the less actual code  and branching in views, the better. Instead I propose

<%= render :partial => 'search_result', :collection => search_results, :empty_template => 'nothing_found' %>



With the nothing_found partial containing the obvious. (I'd rather have a better option name than empty_template but I haven't thought of one so far)

Instead I propose @@@ <%= render :partial => 'search_result', :collection => search_results, :empty_template => 'nothing_found' %> @@@ With the nothing_found partial containing the obvious. version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body: +1 especially with the option for handling simple one line HTML strings [as discussed in #rails-contrib].
version.body-html: +1 especially with the option for handling simple one line HTML strings [as discussed in #rails-contrib].
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body-html:
Revised version of the patch. use cases now include


render :partial => 'record', :collection => @records, :empty => 'Nothing found'
render :partial => 'record', :collection => @records, :empty => {:partial => 'nothing_found'}
render :partial => 'record', :collection => @records, :empty => {:inline => '<%= @something %>'}
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body: I like this concept a lot, but I am wondering if it might not be better to have render take a block that is used if the collection is empty? I'm not sure that makes sense for the other uses of render, but I prefer that syntax over supplying html as a string.
version.body-html: I like this concept a lot, but I am wondering if it might not be better to have render take a block that is used if the collection is empty? I'm not sure that makes sense for the other uses of render, but I prefer that syntax over supplying html as a string.
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body: BTW, a discussion of this can be found "at this thread":http://groups.google.com/group/rubyonrails-core/browse_thread/thread/736fec04ea1e53c8/6684180a26ab5895.
version.body-html: BTW, a discussion of this can be found at this thread.
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body:
In "this thread":http://groups.google.com/group/rubyonrails-core/browse_thread/thread/736fec04ea1e53c8/6684180a26ab5895 some have come to the conclusion that it would be best if "render :collection" returned nil instead of a space for an empty array. This way you can do this with a simple "or" operation.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @records || "Nothing found" %> @@@
Attached is a patch which does this. I moved some stuff around, so that whenever you're trying to render nil, a space is used in the response body so Safari doesn't complain. This way it happens later on in the response chain so "render :collection" doesn't have to be concerned with it.
version.body-html:
In this thread some have come to the conclusion that it would be best if "render :collection" returned nil instead of a space for an empty array. This way you can do this with a simple "or" operation.


<%= render :partial => @records || "Nothing found" %>

Attached is a patch which does this. I moved some stuff around, so that whenever you're trying to render nil, a space is used in the response body so Safari doesn't complain. This way it happens later on in the response chain so "render :collection" doesn't have to be concerned with it.
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body:
*Correction:* you'll need to wrap the render call in parenthesis.
@@@ rhtml <%= render(:partial => @records) || "Nothing found" %> @@@
version.body-html:
Correction: you'll need to wrap the render call in parenthesis.


<%= render(:partial => @records) || "Nothing found" %>
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body: +1 for Ryans patch. Seems the best Ruby-ish solution.
version.body-html: +1 for Ryans patch. Seems the best Ruby-ish solution.

version.body: What about the case where you want something more complex than a simple string rendered when the collection is empty?

version.body:
RSL,

version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body: Ryan, why not checking for collection.blank? so that it doesn't fail with nils? Other than that I'm +1.
version.body-html: Ryan, why not checking for collection.blank? so that it doesn't fail with nils? Other than that I'm +1.
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body-html:
@RSL, as Damian mentioned you can toss it into a helper. Or you can just render a partial right here.


<%= render(:partial => @records) || render(:partial => 'empty') %>

@Damian, I tried this briefly but it still errors out with nil. I don't think the fix is that simple so it should probably go in its own ticket.
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body: Nevermind, found the problem. Attached is an updated patch which also returns nil when nil is passed.
version.body-html: Nevermind, found the problem. Attached is an updated patch which also returns nil when nil is passed.

version.body:
(from [a8ece12fe2ac7838407954453e0d31af6186a5db]) Return nil instead of a space when passing an empty collection or nil to 'render :partial' [#791 state:resolved]
Signed-off-by: Joshua Peek <josh@joshpeek.com> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/a8ece12fe2ac7838407954453e0d31af6186a5db
version.body-html:
(from [a8ece12fe2ac7838407954453e0d31af6186a5db]) Return nil instead of a space when passing an empty collection or nil to 'render :partial' [#791 state:resolved]

Signed-off-by: Joshua Peek josh@joshpeek.com http://github.com/rails/rails/co...
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body:
Just a note, this change crashes XML builder templates with empty collections which use this convention:
@@@ @items = [] xml << render( :collection => @items ) @@@
This is because Builder's << operator won't accept nil, and it throws a "can't convert nil to String" error. The easiest workaround seems to be as above, using the || operator with an empty string, but that sure looks funky:
@@@ xml << ( render(:collection => @items) || '' ) @@@
Or else pass in a :locals option and don't use the << convention:
@@@ render( :collection => @items, :locals => {:x => xml} ) @@@
version.body-html:
Just a note, this change crashes XML builder templates with empty collections which use this convention:


@items = []
xml << render( :collection => @items )

This is because Builder's << operator won't accept nil, and it throws a "can't convert nil to String" error. The easiest workaround seems to be as above, using the || operator with an empty string, but that sure looks funky:


xml << ( render(:collection => @items) || '' )

Or else pass in a :locals option and don't use the << convention:


render( :collection => @items, :locals => {:x => xml} )
version.title: Add empty_template option when rendering a collection

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
